sourceDesc.p:
This publication constitutes a remediation of the printed REED collections - Inns of Court, Ecclesiastical London, and Civic London to 1558. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.
Ecclesiastical London
Mary C. Erler
University of Toronto Press and The British Library. 2008
504
978-0-8020-9858-0 978-0-7123-5024-2
Inns of Court

Civic London to 1558

3 1795
978-1-84384-399-3

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

REED London Online is a prototype online collection developing from the Records of Early English Drama (REED) in partnership with the Canadian Writing Research Collaboratory (CWRC) and supported by Bucknell University. It aims to establish an openly accessible online scholarly and pedagogical resource of London-centric documentary, editorial, and bibliographic materials related to performance, theatre, and music spanning the period 1100-1642. With support from an NHPRC-Mellon Planning Grant for Digital Edition Publishing Cooperatives and CANARIE Research Software Program grants, REED London is creating new environments for scholarly presentation of archival materials gathered from legal, ecclesiastical, civic, political, and personal archival sources in and around London. The objective of the REED London project team is to build a stable, extensible publication environment that optimizes access to these compiled materials in ways that respond to scholars’ research interests across disciplines. Consulting with other planning grant recipients will be invaluable to ensuring that REED London’s production and publication environment is in line with standards laid out in the NHPRC-Mellon grant objectives. It is hoped that the progress REED London and CWRC make will also inform the larger dialogue about best practices among funded teams.

category.catDesc: All Hallows by the Tower Muniments Room

row.cell: Master of the Revells
Mr Stevens./
Mr Sanderson./

div.ab: At this Councell every one of the Masters of the bench and the Assotiattes therevnto are rated and taxed to paie the somme of ffower pounds towards the Charge of the Maske that is intended to be presented by the gentlemen of this howse and of the middle Temple at his Maiesties Courte of at whitehall vppon the ffourtenth ffourtenth for fifteenth daie of ffebr.arij next at the marriage of the Ladie Elizabeth her grace with the Countee Palentine of Rhene And every vtterbarrester of this howse is rated to paie towards the same the somme of ffiftie shillings and every other gentleman of this howse vnder the barr the somme of Thirty shillings/

The Masters of the Bench and others that haue lent and shall lend any mony towards the Charges of the maske to be presented at the Courte at the marriage of the Ladie Elizabeth her grace with the Counteee Palentine of Rhene shalbe repaid there mony soe lent at such tyme at such tyme as the same can be gotten vpp./

Whereas Mr Pyne now deceased sometymes one of the Masters of the bench haue given tenne pounds towards the building of the new Chappell the same to be paid when the said Chappell shalbe in building And Mr Pyne his sonne being an vtterbarrester of this howse being his executor is Content to deliuer the said Tenne pounds to the Masters of the bench they to vse the same at theire pleasure till the said Chappell shalbe in building and then the same to be imployed towards the building of the said Chappell It is therefore ordered that the said tenne pounds shalbe received by Mr Spencer the appointed Treasurer for for for for: dittography the monyes to be Collected for the late maske presented to the kings Maiesties Courte at whithall at the marriage of the Ladie Elizabeth her grace with the Counte Palentine of Rhene./

Mr Cheeke is to lend towards the Charge of the said maske the somme of tenne pounds to be paid by him to Mr Spencer by theise daie seaven nighttheise daie seaven night: 7 May 1613 which money to be repaid assone as Conveniently may be
Mr Roberte Riche is to lend the like somme of tenne pounds for that purpose to be paid as aforesaid and to be repaid as aforesaid./

Mr Randall is to lend towards the maske the somme of xx li. marks and the same to be paid to Mr Spencer by this daie seavennightthis daie seavennight: 11 May 1613 And the same xx li. marks to be paid repaid to Mr Randall as soone as mony can Conveniently be gotten vpp./

Mr Cheeke and Mr Palmer are seuerally to lend the seuerall sommes of x40 li. towards the charge of the late Maske and then to paie the same before the end of this terme to Mr Spencer or els which of them then shall fayle in payment to fforfaite xl s. to the vse of the howse and for default of payment of the said x li. the chamber of him that shall make default to be sequestred to the vse of the howse./

It appeareth by a petition now exhibited by Roger Garners that he is paid by the Cheife Butler the somme of iij li. parcell of the somme of vj li. ix s. ij d. which he had laid out to Mr Long for one of the Masking suites which somme of iij li. Master Treasurer shalbe allowed vppon his accounte./
The Charge of Mr Christofer Brooke Expenditor for the Maske

row.cell: Received Received: i corrected from v at seuerall tymes from the 27th of Ianuary: 1612 vntill the 16th of Iune 1613: of Mr Spencer Threasurer for the reiciptes and disbursmentes towards the Maske at Courte
Received of the deputie Treasurer of the Temple
Mr Brooke his accompt of the disbursments of the same./
Inprimis, to Thomas Watson Taylor for stuffes & Lace
Item to Thomas Pittes Butler for overplus of the Maskers Diet and fier

Item to Mr Anton Mercer for diuerse parcells of Clothe
of Silver

Item to Mr Smith mercer dwelling in St Martins for 144 yards of gold stuffe at 7 s. a yard, 8 s. odd mony abated,8 s. odd mony abated: ie, 1008s was rounded to the nearest pound 50 li. for 6 yards6: for 60 of fflaunders Sattin at 5 s. a yard 15 li.
Item to Mr Morrice Imbroderer for Imbrodering worke ffor the sommes abouesaid disbursed Mr Spencer tooke acquittances
Item more toThomas Watson Taylor for makeing all the maskeing apparell and for lyninges and other thinges by him disbursed and sett downe in his bill
Item more to Thomas Pittes Butler for overplus of the Maskers dyett and fyer
16 li.
Item more to Mr Morrice Imbroderer for Imbrodering worke in his Bill
Item to Mr Barlowe Imbroderer for the like worke

Item to Mr Inigoe Iohnes towards the workes for the Hall
and streete
Item to Mr Roberte Iohnson for musicke and songes
45 li.
Item to Mr Roberte Iohnes Haberdasher for ffeathers and Triminge of suites and head attires
Item to Iohn Banckes Coachmaker for Caroches hier and Coachmakers worke
Item to the Trumpetters
10 li.
Item to Charles Hilyarde Charles Hilyarde: ie, Helliar, a porter for a hatt band and feather
Item to the Actors musicions &c for gloues Ribbin and other thinges the maske nighte
Item rewards to Coachmen for ffower Coaches
Item to a Porter for going to Sir Norrice Bartlettes howse for horses and saddles
Item to BaughanBaughan: B corrected from Mr one of the Marshalles for buying him hatt and feather
Item to a 3 porters for ffetching Horses
Item for horsemeate at the At Antiloppthe Antilopp: the Antelope Inn on the south side of Holborn for 4 horses one night and to the Osteler
Item for bringing a greate saddle
Item to a porter for going home with horses
Item for one dozen of white Torches
Item to Mr Maunder Taylor to hyer horses withall
Item for twelue dozen of pointes
Item to Mr Ingrams man for buying himhim: ie, Mr Ingram a hatt band and feather

Item for Heminges boyHeminges boy: William Heminges, 10-year-old son of John Heminges, actor-manager of the king’s men for a payre stockingespayre stockinges: for payre of stockinges (?) 8 s. for a payre of white shoos 3 s. 8 d. a payre of gloues 16 d. Carnation Ribben 2 s. 6 d.
Item to the players of Tabers and pipes
Item to 3 porters for Carrying Torches and attending
Item to Thomas the Porter
Item to Baugham one of the Marshalls
Item for Torches
13 li.
Item to Robert the Porter for his paynes
Item to ffrauncis Pearson for 80 backebacke: for blacke (?) Capps
Item to Mr Tristram Mr Tristram: John Tristram, barrister which he disbursed for hier of 13 horses and three mens attendance
Item more to Mr Tristram which he disbursed for 18 paire of gantlett gloves at three shillinges a payre 2 li. 14 s. To ffower Torche bearers 4 s.
Item to Robert Barwicke for three Tyers
Item to 9 4eading doubtful: possibly 90 corrected to 94 backebacke: for blacke (?) boyes
Item to the groomesgroomes: g corrected from another letter of the kinges stables
Item to Mr Hamerton for the musicions and Actors dinner the Maskeing daie
Item to Mr Goodman which he disbursed for 14 payre of shoos for the Baboones 1 li. 15 s. for 12 payre of gloues 14 s. to a Coachman 2 s.
Item for pins

Item to Mr Hackwells man which he disbursed for howse Roome for horses and bread and beare 3 s. for bringing 2 horses 12 d. to a Coachman 5 s. for bringing 3 horses 2 s. to a Coachman 2 s. 6 d. for horse meate 1 s. 9 d. for pins 12 d.
Item to the vizard maker
23 li.
Item to the Saddler for yellowe footeclothes and bridles
Item to Richard Ansell the kinges matlayer
Item to Thomas Brewer Cordiner for 27 payre of buskins makinge
Item to Hudson the Overseerre of Carpenters for his paynes for beating downe Master Attorney walls 5 s. and to his men for the like and other worke 3 s. 4 d.
Item to the kinges vshers of the Hall
Item to Thomas Cutting Iohn Dowland and Phillip Rosseter for playing of Lutes every one of them 2 li. 10 s.
Item to Mr Thomas fforde for playing of Lute 2 li. 10 s. and more for setting songes vsed at the maske 5 li., and for Mathias Iohnson for singing 2 li.
Item to Iohn Sturte Robert Taylor Roberte Dowland Thomas Davies for playing of Lutes every one of them 2 li.
Item to Mr IonasMr Ionas: Jonas Wrench, musician to Prince Henry and Mr Mynars two of the musicions for the maske
Item to Thomas Daye for (blank)

Item to 7 singing men vizt. Iohn Drue William Godball Iohn ffrost Davies one of the Queresters Marke Thwaites Walter Porter and Richard Ball every one of them, 2 li. saving Davies whoe had boutbout: for but 1 li. 13 s.
Item to Mrs IohnesMrs Iohnes: Joan, Judith, or Mary Jones, sisters of Inigo Jones for her brother Mr Inego Iohnes
Summa totalis of the money disbursed is
Whereof abated 60 li. and the money disbursed by Lincolnes Inne onely amountes to
Ramanet vndisbursed

div.ab: We haue sene an acquittance for ffiftie pounds paid to Inigoe Iones: and we are satisfied that the other 50 li. was paid thoughe there was noe acquittance shewed
Some of the petty paymentes wee haue allowed thoughe there were noe acquittances taken and we haue seene acquittances for the rest./
Et de ix li. ij s. viij d. receptis de eodem Iohanne pro Surplusagia Rotulorum Musicorum et Carbonorum...
And (the accountant renders account) of £9 2s 8d received from the same John for the balance due from the musicians’ rolls and for coals...

div.p: Chapman’s Memorable Masque was performed in Whitehall Palace hall on 15 February 1612/13, the day after the marriage of Princess Elizabeth and the count palatine.

Christopher Brooke of Lincoln's Inn (referred to on f 526) served as general treasurer for the masque presented jointly with the Middle Temple, an arrangement repeated in 1633-4 for all four Inns. Brooke's accounts, which are remarkably comprehensive, should be compared to loose papers from the Middle Temple, and to the text of the masque. Thomas Pittes (referred to on f 526) was under-butler and chief butler from 1603 until 1623, when he was sacked for embezzlement (see Lincoln's Inn Black Book 7, f 88). The 'workes for the Hall and streete' were the scenery for the stage in the palace hall and the triumphal chariots for the procession from the city to Whitehall. On Richard Ansell (referred to on f 527), the king's matmaker, see also the Declared Accounts of the Treasurer of the Chamber, 1612-13 and 1613-14.
'Item to Hudson the Overseerre (referred to on f 527) has strayed from the building accounts on ff 522–3v for new lodgings for the attorney general, Sir Henry Hobart.

Of the musicians listed on f527v, most appear in court records for 1612–13 as members of either Prince Henry’s servants or the gentlemen of the Chapel: see Andrew Ashbee (ed), Records of English Court Music, vol 4 (Snodland, Kent, 1991). The exceptions are Robert Dowland, Thomas Davies, William Godball, and Mark Thwaites, who may have been borrowed from other bands and choirs.
